title: 110_s1891
content: IMMUNITY FOR REPORTS OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST ACTIVITY OR SUSPICIOUS BEHAVIOR AND RESPONSE. Immunity is granted to individuals who report suspected terrorist activity or suspicious behavior in good faith and based on reasonable suspicion. They are protected from civil liability under any law for making such reports. However, this immunity does not apply if the report is known to be false or made with reckless disregard for the truth. Additionally, immunity is also provided for the response to such reports. Immunity is granted to authorized officials who respond to covered activity in good faith. They have qualified immunity from civil liability for their actions, as long as they act reasonably and in accordance with applicable law. Qualified immunity protects authorized officials from civil liability if they take reasonable action in good faith to respond to reported activity. This immunity does not affect other defenses, privileges, or immunities available to officials. In this section, authorized officials immune from civil liability can recover reasonable costs and attorney fees from the plaintiff. The term "authorized official" includes employees or agents of passenger transportation systems, Department of Homeland Security, or other entities responsible for security. The term "covered activity" refers to any suspicious transaction or occurrence involving a passenger transportation system indicating potential law violations. This includes individuals preparing to engage in illegal activities related to passenger security. The term "passenger transportation" includes public transportation, over-the-road bus transportation, and intercity passenger rail transportation. It relates to violations of law concerning threats to passenger safety, security, and terrorism. The term "passenger transportation" includes intercity passenger rail, passenger vessel, waterborne transportation, and air transportation of passengers. The term "passenger transportation system" refers to entities providing passenger transportation using vehicles and related infrastructure. The term "vehicle" is defined as per section 1992(16) of title 18, United States Code. This section will be effective immediately upon enactment of the Act and applies to activities and claims thereafter.
